bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Rojas, April 10, 1945

div1.p: Hench is relieved to hear that Building No. 1 was not destroyed during the latest hurricane. He assures Rojas that he will continue his campaign to raise funds for its preservation. He describes his visit with Mabel Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Rojas, April 10, 1945
div1.opener:
PSH/cb
10 April, 1945
Senorita Maria Teresa Rojas
Finca San Jose
Redencion Marianao
Havana, Cuba
My dear Senorita Rojas:
div1.p:
Thank you very much for your nice letter of March 17th.
I am greatly relieved to hear that the little building connected with
Walter Reed and the discovery of the cause of yellow fever, was not
destroyed in the recent hurricane, but was remarkably, spared. It is
difficult to understand why it was spared, although, as I remember it,
there is a rather definite slope of the land downward from your home to
the little building and I suppose that the force of the wind coming in
from the ocean hit your home in full force and may have passed over the
little building, deflected upward, due to the slope of the land. In any
event, I am very happy that it was spared. I have written to Mr. Moran,
asking him to see what can be done about protecting the little building
against a future hurricane. I am willing to pay for some such protection,
either to have a stout, strong frame put around it or have some other
method of protection until we can enclose it in a suitable permanent
building. I have also discussed with Mr. Moran possible methods for pro-
tecting it from termites. I wrote to our Department of Agriculture here,
asking for some information on how to protect the little building from
termites. They sent me instructions which I, in turn, have sent to Mr.
Moran and hope that he can get some Government Agent in Cuba to carry out
the protective measures. If not, I am prepared to continue money to have
a civilian do this if it does not cost too much.

I am very sorry that the War and my military duties have pre-
vented me from continuing the campaign to raise funds for the preser-
vation of the little building, but I can assure you that I propose to
continue this as soon as possible. In the meantime, if there is anything
you can do to maintain the interest of the local authorities, such as
Doctor Ramos and Senor Macia, I would appreciate it greatly.

Did I ever tell you a little incident that occurred when I
was visiting Mrs. Jesse Lazear in California two years ago? She is the
widow of the doctor who died during the yellow fever experiments, and
for whom Camp Lazear was named. She was showing me some old pictures
Sheet Two
To: Senorita Maria Teresa Rojas
PSH/cb
10 Apr. 1945
which she had, herself, taken in Cuba in 1900. She visited Doctor
Lazear for a few months. She used to wander around Marianao with her
little camera. In her photograph album, I recognized a very familiar
house and, excitedly, I asked her what the house was. She said, “Oh,
I don't know; it was just one of the nicest houses around there and I
was interested in the Cuban architecture. I wandered by and took this
picture. Nobody was there living in the house at the time, as I remember
it; at least, I saw no one. One or two goats were graving in the front
yard, and the shrubbery and lawn were not kept up”. She was amased when
I told her that it was a picture of the Finca San Jose, your house, and
a few months later became the site of the Camp named after her husband.
Did I ever send you one of those pictures of here? I had it copied and
will be glad to send you one.

closer.signed:
PHILIP S. HENCH, Lt. Col., M.C.
Chief of the Medical Service
